items.title: Ambiguity in readme regarding "newline"
items.body:
Hi -- thanks for this very useful library.

I've been migrating some legacy code, and have a question about the recommended mode of opening files in the README.

Where the example says `newline=''` should that be `newline=b''` or `newline=u''`, or is it intentionally bytes on Python 2, and unicode on Python 3?

I hope that makes sense. Thanks for your assistance.

items.title: Include tests in source tarball
items.body:
Please include tests in the source tarball for packaging purposes, otherwise e.g. rpm `%check` runs 0 tests and unfortunately passes as if successfully.

https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:jayvdb:coala/python-backports.csv

items.title: Bug using `delimiter` argument in csv.DictReader
items.body:
What works with Python 3's csv module

    >>> from backports import csv
    >>> import io
    >>> f = io.open("cache/register_activity.tsv", encoding='utf-8')
    >>> for row in csv.DictReader(f, delimiter='\t'):                               
    ...   print(row)
    ... 
    # correctly prints out several rows from my file

What gives me an error with the csv module from backports (installed using `sudo -H pip install backports.csv`)
    
    >>> from backports import csv
    >>> import io
    >>> f = io.open("cache/register_activity.tsv", encoding='utf-8')
    >>> for row in csv.DictReader(f, delimiter='\t'):                               
    ...   print(row)
    ... 
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports/csv.py", line 615, in $_init__
        self.reader = reader(f, dialect, *args, **kwds)
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports/csv.py", line 232, in $_init__
        raise TypeError('Invalid dialect parameters')
    TypeError: Invalid dialect parameters

items.title: Namespace package does not appear to be properly defined
items.body:
This is a weird one, which we noticed a while back but I didn't bother tracking down until today.

When anyone tries to import `pkg_resources`, which is [provided by setuptools](http://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pkg_resources.html), it will parse through all of your Python modules to determine what packages exist. An `ImportWarning` is triggered because, while the `backports` directory exists, it does not contain a `__init__.py` file so it's not technically a Python package. This does not appear to have any negative impact on how it enumerates the Python packages, but it is a sign that the namespace package is not properly being set up.

You can verify that this issue exists with the latest version, 1.0.5, by running the following command. I've included the output that I'm getting for reference.

```python
$ python -W error::ImportWarning -c 'import pkg_resources;'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2927, in <module>
    @_call_aside
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2913, in _call_aside
    f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2952, in _initialize_master_working_set
    add_activation_listener(lambda dist: dist.activate())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 956, in subscribe
    callback(dist)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2952, in <lambda>
    add_activation_listener(lambda dist: dist.activate())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2515, in activate
    declare_namespace(pkg)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2097, in declare_namespace
    _handle_ns(packageName, path_item)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2031, in _handle_ns
    loader = importer.find_module(packageName)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/pkgutil.py", line 186, in find_module
    file, filename, etc = imp.find_module(subname, path)
ImportWarning: Not importing directory '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports': missing __init__.py
```

I can verify that the namespace package is in fact missing the `__init__.py` file by checking out the package directory.

```bash
$ ls /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/backports
configparser  csv.py  csv.pyc
```

I'll note that while I included the reduced scope example of directly importing the module, we were seeing this in the wild while running both the `unittest` and `pytest` test runners.

items.title: backports.csv uses incorrect default for Dialect.quotechar
items.body:
Take the following example:

```python
from __future__ import unicode_literals
import io

from backports import csv


class CustomDialect(csv.Dialect):
    delimiter = '\t'
    skipinitialspace = False
    lineterminator = '\n'
    escapechar = None
    quoting = csv.QUOTE_NONE


csv.writer(io.StringIO(), CustomDialect)
```

If run with `backports.csv`, this causes a crash:
```
» env/bin/python broken_dialect.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "broken_dialect.py", line 15, in <module>
    csv.writer(io.StringIO(), CustomDialect)
  File "…/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/backports/csv.py", line 193, in __init__
    self.strategy = strategies[self.dialect.quoting](self.dialect)
  File "…/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/backports/csv.py", line 51, in __init__
    quotechar=re.escape(self.dialect.quotechar))
  File "…/env/lib/python2.7/re.py", line 210, in escape
    s = list(pattern)
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
```

If we instead replace the `from backports import csv` with `import csv`, and run under Python3, (i.e., we use the module that this backport should be backporting):

```
» python3 broken_dialect.py
»
```
All is fine.

`backports.csv` appears to expect that the dialect _always_ specifies a `quotechar`, even when (as this dialect does) the dialect is not going to need quoting at all, by specifying `csv.QUOTE_NONE`. This also contradicts the documentation for the vanilla module, which states,

> `Dialect.quotechar`
> A one-character string used to quote fields containing special characters, such as the _delimiter_ or _quotechar_, or which contain new-line characters. **It defaults to `'"'`.**

(bold emphasis mine)

We can work around it by specifying some dummy character for `quotechar`, but that feels silly, and misleads any reader into thinking there might _be_ a quote character / it contradicts the use of `csv.QUOTE_NONE`.

items.title: README.rst -- Error in code sample
items.body:
There is an error in the code sample: replace `writerows` by `writerow` (without "s"):

Here is the fix:

    def write_csv(filename, rows):
        with io.open(filename, 'w', newline='', encoding='utf-8') as f:
            writer = csv.writer(f)
            for row in rows:
                writer.writerow(row)

items.title: backports/__init__.py missing from pip install
items.body:
When I install backports in a custom directory that is part of my python path like this:

    pip install backports.csv --target $TARGET

The `$TARGET/backports/` directory is missing a `__init__.py` file which makes this not load in python2.7.  If I `touch $TARGET/backports/__init__.py`, it works.

items.title: quotes are not preserved in value
items.body:
I have data which is comma separate. In one of column there is quotes for initial word. I want to preserve that quotes.
Data : '"Why,me :P:P","Nature"_is_what_we_see'
My code is : 
reader = csv.reader(TextIOWrapper(BytesIO(b'"Why,me :P:P","Nature"_is_what_we_see')), delimiter=u',')
actual output : [u'Why,me :P:P', u'Nature_is_what_we_see']
expected output : [u'Why,me :P:P', u'"Nature"_is_what_we_see']

When I give input as '"Why,me :P:P",Nature"_is"_what_we_see' then it correctly gives output as [u'Why,me :P:P', u'Nature"_is"_what_we_see']

Note:
If we give escape for double quotes and add parameter escapechar="\\" then it works fine. But I don't have permissions to change the data.

Please correct me if I am going in wrong direction.

items.title: QUOTE_NONNUMERIC broken for Decimal
items.body:
On Python 3, using (the built-in) `csv.writer(f, quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONNUMERIC)` leaves instances of `decimal.Decimal` unquoted:

```
import csv
import io
from decimal import Decimal
with io.open('test.csv', 'w') as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f, quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONNUMERIC)
    writer.writerow([10.0, Decimal('10.0'), '10.0'])
```

yields `10.0,10.0,"10.0"`, i.e. both the `float` and the `Decimal` instance aren't quoted.

However, using `backports.csv` 1.0 from PyPI, the result is `10.0,"10.0","10.0"`, i.e. the `Decimal` instance is quoted.

The problem is that `backports.csv` [checks for a fixed set of numerical types](https://github.com/ryanhiebert/backports.csv/blob/5706aad1af025c0f196ce4a655e57f64ccb84d16/src/backports/csv.py#L152) (`int`, `float`, `complex`), whereas it should [check against `numbers.Number`](http://stackoverflow.com/a/3441601/857390) instead.

A workaround:

```
from backports import csv
import numbers
csv.number_types = (numbers.Number,)
```

items.title: newline param in open method
items.body:
I suggest change **readme.rst** and add a remark when is a good practice add **newline** param to **open** method. 

See footnotes in documentation: https://docs.python.org/3/library/csv.html

If you don't put this parameter then parameter **lineterminator** gives problems. In my case adds an extra blank line to save a csv.

```
from backports import csv
import io

def read_csv(filename):
    with io.open(filename, newline='', encoding='utf-8') as f:
        for row in csv.reader(f):
            yield row

def write_csv(filename, rows):
    with io.open(filename, 'w', newline='', encoding='utf-8') as f:
        writer = csv.writer(f)
        for row in rows:
            writer.writerows(row)
```

items.title: Dialect bytes parameters
items.body:
Let's give a better error message when the dialect parameters are bytes instead of text.

References #9

items.title: Interferes with other backports on Python 3 when pip installed as --user
items.body:
When trying to test #9 on Python 3, I found that installing `backports.csv` on Python hides `backports.shutil_get_terminal_size` (on Arch Linux, Python 3.5.1):

``` bash
$ python -c 'import backports.shutil_get_terminal_size'
$ pip install --user backports.csv
Collecting backports.csv
  Using cached backports.csv-1.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: backports.csv
Successfully installed backports.csv-1.0.1
$ python -c 'import backports.shutil_get_terminal_size'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: No module named 'backports.shutil_get_terminal_size'
```

This may be a more general issue with namespace packages installed in different locations in the `PYTHONPATH`, in which case feel free to close this. I think `backports.shutil_get_terminal_size` was installed as a dependency of IPython, which it seems I did not install in the local user packages.

items.title: Invalid dialect parameters
items.body:
For some reason, specifying `delimiter` raises `TypeError('Invalid dialect parameter.')`:

``` python
from io import BytesIO, TextIOWrapper
from six import PY2
if PY2:
    from backports import csv
else:
    import csv

reader = csv.reader(TextIOWrapper(BytesIO(b'One\tTwo\tThree')), delimiter='\t')
print(next(reader))
```

Running this on Python 3.5 gives:

```
['One', 'Two', 'Three']
```

On Python 2.7:

``` python
>>> reader = csv.reader(TextIOWrapper(BytesIO(b'One\tTwo\tThree')), delimiter='\t')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/backports/csv.py", line 233, in __init__
    raise TypeError('Invalid dialect parameters')
TypeError: Invalid dialect parameters
```

Setting `dialect` to `excel-tabs` seems to work, but I think the delimiter specification should work in a proper backport.

items.title: Documentation correction: need to use io.open()
items.body:
The README right now says to open the file with:

```
with TextIOWrapper(open(filename, 'rb'), encoding='utf-8') as f:
```

This works in Python 3, but not Python 2.  TextIOWrapper needs a "stream", not just a "file".  In Python 3, `open` is the same thing as `io.open`, and it returns a stream.  In Python 2, `io.open` returns a stream, but `open` returns a file.

If you try to run this as written in Python 2, you get an error (no "readable" attribute).

The simple fix is to use `io.open` instead of `open` (for both the reading and writing cases), and it works in both Python 2 and 3.

items.title: Feature request: return full error messages to caller
items.body:
When I make a call like:

```
from backports import csv
writer = csv.writer(f, delimiter=',', quoting=csv.QUOTE_ALL)
```

I get:

```
TypeError: Invalid dialect parameters
```

That may well be true, but it would be a lot more helpful if it reported what the actual problem was.  In backports.csv/csv.py around line 183, it's doing:

```
try:
    ...
except Error:
    raise TypeError('Invalid dialect parameters')
```

which throws away the helpful error message reported by `Dialect.validate()`.

items.title: Missing var in README
items.body:
In the `write_csv` example in the README, it looks like there should be a line like:

```
writer = csv.writer(f)
```

(possibly with some other parameters?).

items.title: Not in PyPI?
items.body:
The README says to install via:

```
pip install backports.csv
```

But I don't see anything by this name:

```
$ pip search backports.csv
$ pip install backports.csv
Collecting backports.csv
  Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement backports.csv (from versions: )
No matching distribution found for backports.csv
```

I don't see anything [on the PyPI webpage](https://pypi.python.org/pypi?%3Aaction=search&term=backports.csv&submit=search), either.

Does this module still remain to be packaged?  (It looks super useful!)
